metadata.title: Interfacial phenomena and formation of nano-particles in porous ZrB2–40 vol. % B4C UHTC

sections.text:
The micro/nanostructual development, sintering process and its controlling mechanisms as well
as the interfaces between ZrB2 and B4C particles were investigated using high resolution SEM, XRD and TEM analyses in a hot pressed ZrB2–40 vol. % B4C ceramic composite. Two types of porosities (open and closed) were observed in the microstructure of fabricated porous composite,
which were caused by different factors. The results showed that the sintering process was
encouraged by the formation of liquid phases at the interfaces, elimination of oxide impurities
from the surfaces of ZrB2 particles (due to the chemical reactions with B4C particles and their free carbon), plastic deformation of ZrB2 grains and the diffusion of carbon and/or boron atoms from B4C toward ZrB2 particles. A mixture of nano-particles and nano-porosities at the submicron thickness amorphous ZrB2/B4C interfaces is detected and discussed in detail. Keywords: Ultrahigh temperature ceramic; Interface; Sintering; Nano-particles/pores.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Zirconium diboride (ZrB2) as an important member of ultra-high temperature ceramics (UHTCs) has very special physicochemical properties such as high melting point, high hardness, excellent
chemical and wear resistance and high thermal stability. These unique characteristics are the key
factors for the broad applications of this material in various fields; e.g. thermal protection
systems (TPS), wear parts applied in reentry vehicles, high temperature electrodes, molten metal
crucibles, nozzles and cutting tools [1-8].
Boron carbide (B4C) possesses a combination of interesting properties such as low density, extremely high hardness, high bending strength, high neutron absorption and very high wear
resistance. Hence, B4C is also a favorable ceramic candidate in several engineering applications, such as nozzles, armors, reactors and cutting tools [9-13].
Despite the aforementioned fascinating properties and potential applications of ZrB2 and B4C ceramics, their developing applications especially in the form of monolithic ceramics is
somewhat limited due to the challenges of poor sinterability, low self-diffusion coefficients and
strong covalent bonding. The fabrication of fully dense ZrB2 or B4C ceramics in the absence of specific additives or secondary phases generally requires complicated processes and high
sintering temperatures of >2000 °C through hot pressing process. However, the acquired
products by this method have generally deficiencies and drawbacks including the undesirable
grain growth and low mechanical properties. Therefore, several researches have been explored to
develop the advanced ZrB2–SiC and B4C–SiC composites with appropriate and improved properties in recent years [10, 14-22]. The ability of SiC in constraining the surface oxide
impurities of both ZrB2 and B4C is known as one of the major causes for enhancing the sinterability of these ceramics, which is due to the existence of carbon in the structure of silicon
carbide and promoting the reactive sintering phenomenon [4, 23-29]. A similar effect can be
possibly occurred by using any other carbon-containing compounds as a reinforcement phase in
ZrB2-based ceramics and particularly in B4C [30, 31]. Consequently, the possibility of improving the weaknesses of the ZrB2–B4C counterpart systems can be considered as an interesting research area requiring further investigations by advanced
methods and techniques. It has been reported that the addition of B4C into ZrB2 not only assists the sintering process in microwave heating process, but also promotes the densification behavior
in pressureless sintering technique [30]. However, to the best of our knowledge, there are very
limited research studies and publications on ZrB2–B4C ceramic composites sintered by the hot pressing method. Therefore, it is an important issue to investigate the microstructure, sintering
process, densification mechanisms and mechanical/thermal properties of this system.
He et al. reported the effect of ZrB2 contents on B4C–ZrB2 ceramics fabricated by hot pressing at 1950 °C for 60 min under an applied pressure of 30 MPa. They found that the addition of ZrB2 not only considerably assists the sintering process and produces the fully dense samples, but also
improves the mechanical properties of the hot pressed composites [10].
Although the presence of the porosity may play a negative role in case of mechanical properties
for ZrB2-based composites as well as their oxidation resistance, it has been concluded that the thermal shock resistance of the composite can be significantly enhanced due to the presence of
deliberately formed porosities [32-34]. From another point of view, porosities can lead to a lower
density composite formation, which has probably a broader structural applications and in
particular for ZrB2-based composites usages e.g. aerospace components. In the latter case, recent developments in surface treatments have grown opportunities to counteract the porosity-derived
drawbacks in ZrB2-based materials. For example, researches have proved that laser treatments
can form a glassy borosilicate phase [35] and a dense composite layer [36] on the surfaces of
such porous composites. The formed dense layers can enhance the surface oxidation resistance of
the designed synthesized material and also protect the inner regions of the composite from
diffusing oxygen [35]. In addition, very important subsequent properties such as low thermal
conductivity, controlled permeability, high surface area, high specific strength and low dielectric
constant have been introduced as complementary advantages to the tailored porosities in the
engineered ceramic materials [33].
We have recently reported the sintering process of porous ZrB2–B4C binary ceramics which contained 0 to 100 vol. % B4C and hot pressed at 1800 °C for 30 min under 12 MPa. SEM analysis of fracture surfaces showed that the sintering process controls by the formation of ZrO2 phases [37].
The aim of this research is to precisely investigate the microstructural development, progress of
sintering process and interfacial characterization of porous ZrB2–B4C ultra-high temperature ceramic, fabricated by hot pressing method at 1800 °C for 30 min under a relatively low pressure
of 12 MPa, utilizing the latest techniques e.g. transmission electron microscope (TEM), scanning
electron microscope (SEM) and x-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and process
sections.text:
In this research, commercially available ZrB2 powder with an average particle size of 2 μm (Leung Hi-tech Co., China) and B4C powder with an average particle size of 20 μm (Mudanjiang Jingangzuan Boron Carbide Co., China) were purchased and used as raw materials. Such
relatively large B4C particles were applied to promote the formation of open porosities in as-
sintered sample. ZrB2 powder was dry-mixed with 40 vol. % B4C powder by ball mixing at 120 rpm for 60 min in zirconia media. Then the sample with a diameter of 25 mm and a thickness of
5 mm was loaded into a graphite die, which was sprayed with boron nitride (BN) and lined with
flexible graphite foils. Sintering process was performed in a vacuum hot pressing furnace
(Shenyang Weitai Science & Technology Development Co. Ltd., China). The powder mixture
was initially heated at a rate of 15 °C/min up to 1000 °C and then the temperature was kept at
1000 °C for 30 min. Finally the sample was heated at a rate of 12 °C/min up to 1800 °C. An
external pressure of 12 MPa was applied to the sample, for 30 min, after the temperature reached
1800 °C. The sintering furnace was cooled down to the room temperature in a normal path
gradually.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization
sections.text:
Bulk density of the as-sintered sample was measured by the Archimedes’ rule in distilled water
as the immersing medium. Relative density of the hot pressed composite was estimated with
respect to its theoretical density. Based on the true densities of the starting components (ZrB2: 6.1 g/cm 3 and B4C: 2.5 g/cm 3 ), the theoretical density of the sample was calculated by the rule of mixtures. High resolution XRD (HRXRD: Bruker D8 Advance, Germany) characterizations
were carried out on the raw materials and the as-sintered ceramic. The microstructural
characterizations were studied by SEM (Mira3 Tescan, Czech Republic) and also TEM (Philips,
Tecnai F20 S-TWIN, Netherlands) which was operated at 200 kV. The TEM specimen was
prepared by focusing the ion beam (Model: 601, Gatan Inc., USA) prior to the TEM
investigations. Chemical analysis was performed using energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS:
DXP-X10P Digital X-Ray Processor).
Results and discussion
Fig. 1 shows the SEM micrographs of fracture surface of the sample. The amounts of open-type
and closed-type porosities in the microstructure of ZrB2–40 vol. % B4C ceramic composite were calculated to be ~24% and 7%, respectively. Although two types of porosities are presented in
the structure of the discussed sample, it appears that they have been initiated from different
motivators. The formation of closed pores can be related to the production of gaseous phases
which release during the sintering process due to the reduction of surface oxide impurities of
ZrB2 (zirconia and boria) by B4C (or free carbon existence). The presence of open channels is perhaps due to the intensive dissimilarity in the particle size of the starting raw materials or gas-
caused gaps between adjacent particles which disturb the sinterability.
The relatively low sintering temperature of 1800 °C, the mainly covalent nature of ZrB2 and B4C bonds and also the large size of the B4C particles caused low sinterability in this research. As it can be clearly seen in Fig. 1a, mostly the particles with small dimensions (e. g. ZrB2) are either joined together or with other large particles. However, there is no considerable connections
between the large particles of B4C. The formation of moss-like phases on the surface of B4C particles, particularly at the ZrB2/B4C interfaces, during the hot pressing process can be seen in Fig. 1b. Such semi-glassy phases have
not been detected in the monolithic B4C ceramics [37]. In addition, it seems that these amorphous moss-like phases contain considerable crystalline nanoparticles. More careful
investigation on the fracture surface of the B4C particle (marked zone in Fig. 1b) reveal a thin covering layer. Such a layer morphologically seems to be a solidified phase on the B4C particle, which contains smaller agglomerated particles with deformed shapes. It appears that such
transient layers can act as precursors for the formation of sintering interface. Hence, the sintering
phenomenon may be conducted by a simultaneous interaction of these solidified layers and the
mentioned moss-like phases. EDS spectrum of the discussed moss-like phase showed high
concentration level of zirconium and oxygen elements, which can be a sign for the
presence/formation of ZrO2 and assistance of the sintering process. It should be noted that diboron trioxide is the only liquid-state phase which can be formed at sintering temperature of
1800 °C in ZrB2–B4C system and commonly solidifies as amorphous phase [38]. Therefore, it is anticipated to detect the feature of amorphous B2O3 phase on the surface of B4C particles in closer views. The detail explanation of this expectation is discussed later in TEM nanographs
investigation section.
Fig. 2 presents the XRD pattern of as-sintered ZrB2–40 vol. % B4C composite. Apparently, the main detected crystalline phases are ZrB2 and B4C; however, the traces of ZrO2 and graphite are also perceivable. Moreover, no detectable sign of amorphous phase is observed in XRD pattern,
which is probably due to the very small amounts of such phases in the final microstructure of the
composite. Subsequently, it can be concluded that the above-mentioned interfacial phases are
consisted of crystalline ZrO2 and graphite nano-particles lied in an amorphous B2O3 bed. Although around 30% of porosities have been finally remained in the structure of hot pressed
sample, it seems that the sintering process has remarkably progressed due to the above-
mentioned phenomena at the ZrB2/B4C interfaces. A bright-field TEM image of the hot pressed ZrB2–40 vol.% B4C composite is presented in Fig. 3. As can be clearly seen, several ZrB2 grains (darker particles) are sintered together and also joined a respectively large B4C particle. Also, the interfacial phases as well as porosities are clearly visible in the central section of the image.
A more detailed view of the interface of ZrB2 particles is presented in Fig. 4. The formation of amorphous phases in vicinity of ZrB2 particle is clearly visible in the mentioned image (black marked areas). The ZrB2 particles not only join B4C particles via forming a nano-scale bonding layer, but also sinter each other very well to enhance the sinterability of the sample. Most of the
ZrB2 grains are equiaxed with an average diameter of 2 μm which are similar to the starting powders. Hence, it appears that the sintering conditions have progressed in a way that the grain
growth phenomenon was not occurred widely.
Some submicron ZrB2 particles (marked) are formed on the surface of the main zirconium diboride grains in a bed of morphologically amorphous phase. The formation of such tiny
particles is verified by the diffraction (DF) pattern (inset of Fig. 4) and may be a result of the
following chemical reaction [31]:
7ZrO2 + 5B4C → 7ZrB2 + 3B2O3 (l) + 5CO (g) (1)
As it can be paraphrased from Eq. 1, the formed submicron ZrB2 particles can float in liquid boria. It can be considered as a reason for some submicron ZrB2 particles moving toward regions other than interfaces of ZrB2/B4C grains. Fig. 5 shows the entrapment of some nano-pores in amorphous layer (marked by arrow). Such
closed nano-scale porosities which have relatively spherical shapes are formed due to the
releasing of gaseous phases during the sintering process through Eq. 1 and also the following
reaction between surface oxide layers and the existed free carbon in B4C starting powder [31, 37]:
ZrO2 + B2O3 (l) + 5C → ZrB2 + 5CO (g) (2)
Carbon monoxide formed on the ZrB2/B4C interfaces (based on Eqs. 1-2) may escape from the structure of the composite due to the external pressure. On one hand, this phenomenon can push
back the particles and promote the formation of open-type porosities. In contrast, the formed CO
can also be entrapped in the liquid amorphous layers and result in the formation of observed
close-type nano-pores at ZrB2/B4C interfaces. However, it seems that the free carbons existed on the surface of B4C particles have not completely participated in Eq. 2 and the unreacted ones have been converted to the graphitized
carbon, may be due to the applied external pressure during the sintering process. The mixture of
nano-sized graphitized carbon together with other nano-particles, which are floated in an
amorphous interfacial layer, is presented in Fig. 6. Formation of graphite is also endorsed by the
XRD pattern (Fig. 2).
As shown in Fig. 7, several dislocations are observed inside the ZrB2 grain. It seems that these dislocations are moving toward the grains boundaries. Accordingly, the ZrB2 grains can be plastically deformed during the hot pressing process due to the applied external pressure. A
similar phenomenon has also been reported for ZrB2–SiC system at temperatures around 1850 °C [39, 40].
Furthermore, the neck formation between the interfacial nanoparticles and ZrB2 matrix is clearly demonstrated in Fig. 7, which is an indication of progression of sintering process at the surface
of particles. It is also notable that the neck formation is promoted by the amorphous phase
(marked by black arrows), which was in liquid state during the sintering process. Consequently,
it can be concluded that the liquid phase sintering mechanism is participating in hot pressing
process as well as the aforementioned mechanisms such as plastic deformation and also chemical
reactions.
A ZrB2/ZrB2 grain boundary is presented in Fig. 8 (marked by white arrows) which seems to be completely clean of any impurity or secondary phases. The presence of surface oxide impurities
(ZrO2 and B2O3) is known as the most important cause of unfavorable grain growth in monolithic ZrB2 ceramics [8, 41]. A similar behavior has been reported for other diboride ceramics such as TiB2 and HfB2 [42-44]. Therefore, the manipulations to eliminate such impurities may potentially decrease the risk of development of grain coarsening phenomenon. In
the present case, chemical reactions (Eqs. 1 and 2) participated in the removal of impurities from
grain boundaries, resulted in inhabiting the extraordinary grain growth of ZrB2 during the hot pressing process.
Fig. 9 shows a layer contained several porosities behind the B4C/ZrB2 interface. The orientation and also the density of such nano-porosities behind the interface addresses the wide diffusion of
atoms from the B4C particles to the interface. Because the diameter of boron and carbon are very small compared to zirconium atoms in ZrB2 and also the high melting point of ZrB2, the diffusion phenomenon develops from B4C particles toward ZrB2 grains. This phenomenon may proceed to the surface of the B4C particles and deplete the carbon and/or boron atoms, and finally the formation of vacancies or ultrafine nano-pores behind the interface. Therefore, it
seems that the sintering process initially starts with the formation of moss-like and liquid phases
at the interfaces, and continues with the plastic deformation in grains and finally terminates with
the diffusion of carbon/boron atoms. The diffusion of carbon and boron atoms from B4C toward ZrB2 particles is also confirmed by a line scan of the interface [37]. It is also reported that the
reduction of oxide impurities leads to higher boron activity, which assists the lattice diffusion
and the sintering process [45-52].
A conclusive drawing shown in Fig. 10 represents the mechanism of interfacial phenomena in
ZrB2–40 vol.% B4C composite based on the former discussions.
Conclusions
Porous ZrB2–40 vol.% B4C composite were fabricated via hot pressing at 1800 °C for 30 min under a pressure of 12 MPa. The interfacial and microstructural characteristics of the composite
were investigated by SEM, TEM and XRD analyses in order to understand the role of interfacial
phenomena in progression of sintering process. The results revealed that the sintering process is
controlled by a combination of interfacial phenomena including the formation of liquid phase at
the interfaces, plastic deformation of the particles and the diffusion of carbon and/or boron atoms
from B4C toward ZrB2 particles. Two types of porosity in the aforementioned composite and their roles in sintering process were also discussed. In addition, a summary of interfacial
phenomena were depicted by a schematic model to simply present the investigation discussion.

metadata.abstractText: The micro/nanostructual development, sintering process and its controlling mechanisms as well as the interfaces between ZrB2 and B4C particles were investigated using high resolution SEM, XRD and TEM analyses in a hot pressed ZrB2–40 vol. % B4C ceramic composite. Two types of porosities (open and closed) were observed in the microstructure of fabricated porous composite, which were caused by different factors. The results showed that the sintering process was encouraged by the formation of liquid phases at the interfaces, elimination of oxide impurities from the surfaces of ZrB2 particles (due to the chemical reactions with B4C particles and their free carbon), plastic deformation of ZrB2 grains and the diffusion of carbon and/or boron atoms from B4C toward ZrB2 particles. A mixture of nano-particles and nano-porosities at the submicron thickness amorphous ZrB2/B4C interfaces is detected and discussed in detail.
